FRESHMEN VICTORIOUS

PRICE, FIVE CENTS

HONOR PROFESSOR ELLIOTT

LACROSSE SEASON TO START

Meeting Held in the Donovan Room to
Commemorate late Head of the
Romance Depart meet.

Practice Has Already Begun and Formal
Merting to be Held Thursday—
All Candidates Out.

A little company of members of
the Hopkins faculty, Romance
language scholars and friends
gathered in the Donovan Room,
yesterday afternoon to pay tributes
to the late Aaron Marshall Elliott,
who was for over twenty years the
head of the department of Romance languages in the University.
President Remsen, members of
the Hopkins staff, former students
and friends told of his life and
services, of his guiding influence in
the development of Roman linguistics, of his pioneer work, and of his
sterling qualities as a man, an
associate, a counsellor and an adviser.
The speakers testified that in
every country his influence is
known and appreciated, and that
the foundation of the Modern
Language Association and of the
Modern Language Notes which for
a quarter of a century he edited,
are monuments to his life which
will never permit the waters of
oblivion to flow over him and enable him to be forgotten.
Idealism, cheerfulness and unselfishness were the three traits
which President Remsen said were
strongly characteristic of his connection with the University and
association with his students and
colleagues. "And when a man had
these three traits," continued Dr.
Remsen, "certain consequences follow. In all of my experience as
a university professor, I do not
recall any instance in whichi.devotion of student and associate to
professor was more marked than
was the case in the Romance department. He was unselfish in
the extreme, and this unselfishness
had its effect in causing his department to be one of the most
harmonious in its work, that it
has been my privilege to know. I
only wish that in every department in every univiersity, there
could be manifested the same untiring devotion and self effacement."
Professor C. Carroll Marden
read a brief account of the life of
Dr. Elliott, and Professors Bright
and Gildersleeve `told of their relations with him as co-members of
the Hopkins faculty. Dr. Edward
C. Armstrong who is to head the
department of Romance languages
told of departmental relations with
Professor Elliott. Mr. George
Whitelock of the Baltimroe bar
spoke from the standpoint of a
friend who had known Dr. Elliott
for 35 years.

A successful season in Hopkins
athletics has just passed, and we
now look forward to further successes. Lacrosse opens its official
season with an organization meeting Thursday, December 8. Head
coach Meyer and assistant coaches
Lowndes and Frank will distribute
information and advice for the
first time in their official capacities.
A number of former Hopkins players and others interested will be
present.
Regular practice has been held
three times a week in the "cage,"
and Captain Hulburt is developing
a very promising squad. The
freshmen are showing up particularly well in their stick work even
at this early stage, and when the
regular lineup begins men of last
year's team may have their hands
"full holding their positions. The
loss of Edmund Clary, Pitts Ralleigh, and several medical men
will be severely felt. However,
there is left a good nucleus of last
year's team and this together with
the afore - mentioned promising
squad, while not by any means
in championship form as yet, furnishes a very good foundation on
which to build hopes for a championship lacrosse team in 1911.
Under Jake's tender care the
"cage" has recently assumed a "lacrosseable" shape. The tan bark has
been entirely removed, and the
ground is being constantly smoothed and watered. We shall miss
ex-coach Chesney's tow-head from
the middle of the "cage," but hope
to find him not infrequently at the
practices. Again, as always, "Bill"
Schmeisser will loom up in the
back-ground as a source of lacrosse
wisdom which can always be depended upon.
The schedule in -rapidly rounding into shape under Manager
li'akel's experienced management.
Games with Navy, Cornell, Harvard, Swarthmore, Lehigh, and
Stevens, are definitely settled;
games with Columbia, Carlisle,
and Mt. Washington are pending.
Every game will be played at Homewood except the Navy and Swarthmore games, and so this bids fair
to be one of the best schedules seen
at Homewood for some time.

names of those subscribers to THE

BALTIMORE, MD., DEC. 5, 1910.

The selection of Dr. Edward F.
Buchner to fill, for the remainder
of this year, the place of Miss
Sarah C. Brooks at the Teachers'
Training School is a great tribute
to the strength and importance of
the youngest department at Flopkins—that of education.
Elsewhere in this issue, we print
one or two good stories clipped from
College World, a new and interesting monthly devoted to the interests
of undergraduates. These little
clashes in the class-room occur
everywhere and numbers of exceedingly funny ones have taken
place here at Hopkins.
Last year in ''Forensics 2," for
instance, Dr. French made the
statement that statistics proved that
married men, as a class, live longer
than single men. Quick as a flash
came the answer from "Teddy"
Will:
"That isn't true literally, Doctor,.
It just seems longer," and then the
class and instructor roared .
This is the kind of material that
TIIE NEWS-LEV-1'ER would like to
print,more of; and so fellows, when
something funny happens, write it
up and send it to us. We will be
glad to use it and you will give
others an opportunity to laugh at
what you think is a good joke.
Gifts to the amount of $13o,000
have been received by the Johns
Hopkins Committee on Endowment and extension during the
past week and certainly make the
outlook for raising of the fund
before the first of the year much
brighter. It came as a sort of
shock when the Committee announced that the whole of the
$75o,000 which has to be collected
in order to get the $250,000 offered
by the General Education Board

will have to be raised by local subscriptions, but the people of Baltimore are responding nobly, and
if contributions flow in at the present rate, no difficulty will be experienced in raising the necessary
funds.
The current issue of the Suwanee
Review contains an article from
the pen of Dr. William Hand
Browne, professor emeritus of English literature, an author whose
communications, Baltimoreans in
general, and Hopkins men in particular, are always glad to welcome.
Dr. Browne writes in an entertaining and scholarly fashion of the
various transformations undergone
by the story of Orpheus and Eurydice on its way from a classic
myth to a mediaeval fairy tale.
The statement of the New York
Evening Post to the effect that
there was here at Hopkins a socialist society in process of formation
does not seem to be as unfounded
as was at first thought. Just a day
before the illustrious Emma Goldman was scheduled to begin her
lectures in Baltimore, THE NEwsLETTER was given an exclusive tip
that some of th.?. students were
helping to advertise her speeches .
by distributing literature, inflammable in color and subject matter,
which represented Miss Goldman to
be the "most talented, but most misrepresented woman in the world,"
and urged everyone to come to the
four meetings.
Our "star reporter, whose name
we withhold for obvious reasons,
was sent out on the story, and
after a labored and careful investigation he discovered the following:
(I.) That eight red posters had
been placed in conspicuous positions in the lower corridor, where
the counterfeit presentments of
professors past and present gazed
benignly down on them.
(2.) That there were sixteen
cards of other colors in the corridor, and that all were prepared
with a view to augmenting socialistic sentiment among the readers.
(3.) That in the building, i. e.,
the classrooms, library, Y.M.C. A.,
etc., there were sixteen and onehalf cards. The missing half could
not be found, although a long and
painstaking search was conducted.
It is thought that some opponent
of the movement destroyed it.
This seems to be prima facie
evidence that some sort of sentiment favorable to the propaganda
of the Socialists exists at this University. We wish, therefore, to
reiterate our protest made in the
last issue of THE NEWS-LETTER,
that with the formation of the Arbitration Society and the rejuvenation of the Glee and Instrumental
Clubs, we have sufficient outside
activities to distract the mind from
study, and that if the door is once
opened to politic' organizations,
there will be no end nor limitation,
and the Republican, Democratic
and Prohibition sororities will immediately follow.

THE NEWS-LETTER, DECEMBER 5, 1910
SUMMER SCHOOL AT HOPKINS

FULTON IS AGAIN HONORED

Six Weeks' Session, from July 5th to
August 16th to be Given for
Teachers.

Star Hopkins Athlete is Elected Captain
of the Football Team for
Next Season:*

It has just been announced that
next summer a special six weeks'
course for teachers will be given
under the auspices of the Johns
Hopkins University. The work
will be designed primarily to meet
the personal and professional needs
of teachers. The school will be
under the direction of Dr. Edward
F. Buchner, professor of education,
and a large number of instructors,
selected because of their marked
ability as teachers and their interest in the special problems which
confront teachers, will co-operate.
The staff will comprise members
of the Hopkins Faculty and representatives from the faculties of
Other institutions. The complete
list will be announced at an early
date and a circular descriptive of
the courses offered will be issued.
It is in response to numerous
requests on the part of the administrators of the schools of Maryland,
and in the hope of increasing its service to the elementary and high
schools, that the University has
undertaken the summer session.
Ever since the beginning of instruction at Hopkins the University
has been noted for the lectures
Which were offered, entirely apart
from the formal courses which had
to be followed for the various degrees. The college courses for
teachers are now in the second year
Qf a very successful operation and
the extension of the work of the
University into this new field ought
to receive enthusiastic support.
Mr. George Lectures.

One of the most interesting and
instructive talks ever given in Levering Hall was given on Thursday
at five o'clock by Mr. W. R.
George, founder of the George
Junior Republic.
There are 175 boys and girls at
the Republic who govern themselves. They elect their own officers, have boy cops, jailers, bankers, and each boy and girl works
for his own living and pays his
board just as any other citizen of
the United States does. They also
have woman's sufferage and discuss all the political problems of
the American public life.

DR. MITCHELL DRAWS CROWD
McCoy Hall Packed to Hear Distinguished Neurologist and Author Lecture on "William Harvey."

That the Baltimore public is not
altogether indifferent to the lectures offered by the University, and
that the size of attendance depends
largely upon the extent of the
lecturer's popularity, was demonstrated last Monday night by the
unusually large and brilliant assembly which thronged McCoy
Hall to hear one of the most illustrious men whom the University
has recently had the honor to entertain. The venerable Dr. Silas
Weir Mitchell, now in his eightysecond year, poet, novelist, antiquarian, physician, and in all these
capacities distinguished, delivered,
at the invitation of the Johns Hopkins Hospital Historical Association, a lecture on "William Harvey," his spiritual ancestor, as he
fondly called him, and practically
the founder of the modern science
of medicine.
Dr. Mitchell is no narrow specialist, but a man of the broadest human interests ; and he treated his
subject, consequently, not as a
scientific abstraction, but as a living hero. He told of William
Harvey's boyhood in the little fishing town of Folkestone, on the
Kentish coast, of his sojourn as a
lesser pensioner at Cains College,
Cambridge; of his anatomical studies under Fabricius, at Aquapendente, at the great Italian University of Padua; of his graduation
from that venerable seat of learning with all the stately and impressive pomp so dear to Italian
tradition—the darkened theatre, the
robed senators of Venice; the opening of the closed books, the kiss
of peace, the goblet crown, the ring
of marriage to the University, the
presentation of the folded diploma.
Dr. Mitchell is a most charming
lecturer. He is not an orator; he
is a speaker of the old school; he
does not scruple to use a ringing
phrase or a flowery sentence when
he thinks such would be effective;
his delivery is hardly such as would
pass in public speaking. Yet it
is a pleasure to listen to him. His
venerable figure, his winning personality, his graceful humor, his
depth of thought, his breadth of
interest, his richness of allusion,
his great store of general knowledge, his youthful enthusiasm, combine to make him one of, the most
entertaining lecturers whom Hopkins has had the pleasure to hear
for a long time. May we enjoy
the pleasure soon again!

REMEMBER

This new volume which deals
with the principles of the science
of argumentation is proportioned
along slightly different lines from
previous educational works which
have been written on the same subject. The discussion of the fundamental principles is very brief, but
to the point, and by far the greater
part of the book is given up to
masterpieces of complete debates
on important questions which have
agitated the country. All of the
great figures in the Senate are represented in the collection, and
this, in addition to furnishing illustrations of the principles discussed
in the early part of the book has
the added advantage of giving to
the general reader these great debates in a collected form. The
manner of saying things in defense
of great principles is secondary to
what has been said, and it is just
as important to know what the
contentions of Lincoln and Webster were, as the manner in which
their arguments were presented.
This volume makes both possible.
In addition there is much new
material in the book on the subject
-of briefing and debating. This has
been carefully selected from the
field of actual contest and is based
on principles which have been
found to work in intercollegiate
debates, and is therefore helpful
because it is practical.

Maryland. Washington College objected last season when Hopkins
claimed this honor,• as Hopkins had
not. played the Chestertown. eleven.

leaves the matter no longer in
doubt, as the Hopkins eleven had
shown itself superior to the other
contenders for the Maryland Championship.

A big mass-meeting, to boost the
track team, will be held tomorrow
afternoon in the trophy room of
the gymnasium. Everyone should
be present, whether he intends to
join the squad or not, so as to
throw some life into the meeting
and make it a.success. A number of
Alumni will be present, and will
make speeches. Captain Fulton will
issue a formal call for candidates
at this meeting.
At the last meeting of the
Athletic Board, Rudolph Alfred
Kocher, a former star athlete of
Leland Stanford University, was
chosen coach of the team for this
year. William E. Hoffman, who
has coached the track squad several years, could not spare the time
necessary to accept the position
again. Kocher is at present attending the Hopkins Medical School.
He will speak at the mass-meeting
tomorrow.
Manager Harold B. Hering is
arranging one of the most ambitious
schedules a Hopkins track team
has ever had. He has a dual meet
with Columbia pending for May
6, and he has definitely scheduled
Pennsylvania, and the University
of Virginia.

Announcement was made Friday
morning that two men had passed
the Rhodes Scholarship examination held at Johns Hopkins University last October. The succesful
students are Bertram Benedict and
Harold Hering, both of whom are
Hor kins men.
Harold Hering is the president
of the senior class and manager
of this year's track team. He was
graduated from the Baltimore City
College in 1907, and has won
scholarships two years in succession at Hopkins. Bertram Benedict is also a graduate of the City
College, class of 1908. He is now
in the junior class at Johns Hopkins, where he took honors last
year.
There are two other candidates
eligible for the scholarship—M. R.
Reid, a graduate of Roanoke College, now a student at the Hopkins Medical School, and J. H.
Hendrickson, a graduate of Western Maryland College and the Harvard Law School. These men took
the examination last year, but
asked that they be considered in
this year's group of candidates.
From these four students one
man must be chosen. No further
examination will be held, but the
scholarship will be awarded by the
committee to the man who, in its
judgment, would best represent
his State and Nation at Oxford.
The general opinion among the
Hopkins undergraduates seems to
be that Harold Hering will receive
the honor. The popularity and athletic ability of the contestants is
generally taken into account. Her:,
ing is highly thought of both by
his classmates and the faculty, and
lie has made a creditable record as
an athlete.
The Rhodes scholarship carries
with it three years' residence at
Oxford, with full tuition and expenses, amounting in all to $1,500.
The recipients of .the scholarships
are granted special privileges.
They may become candidates for
In the
any degree they desire.
immense dining hall at Oxford
they sit at a table by themselves,
separated from the undergraduate
body, but close to the fellows, who
have a special table.

HONOR PROFESSOR ELLIOTT

LACROSSE SEASON TO START

Meeting Held in the Donovan Room to
Commemorate late Head of the
Romance Depart meet.

Practice Has Already Begun and Formal
Merting to be Held Thursday—
All Candidates Out.

A little company of members of
the Hopkins faculty, Romance
language scholars and friends
gathered in the Donovan Room,
yesterday afternoon to pay tributes
to the late Aaron Marshall Elliott,
who was for over twenty years the
head of the department of Romance languages in the University.
President Remsen, members of
the Hopkins staff, former students
and friends told of his life and
services, of his guiding influence in
the development of Roman linguistics, of his pioneer work, and of his
sterling qualities as a man, an
associate, a counsellor and an adviser.
The speakers testified that in
every country his influence is
known and appreciated, and that
the foundation of the Modern
Language Association and of the
Modern Language Notes which for
a quarter of a century he edited,
are monuments to his life which
will never permit the waters of
oblivion to flow over him and enable him to be forgotten.
Idealism, cheerfulness and unselfishness were the three traits
which President Remsen said were
strongly characteristic of his connection with the University and
association with his students and
colleagues. "And when a man had
these three traits," continued Dr.
Remsen, "certain consequences follow. In all of my experience as
a university professor, I do not
recall any instance in whichi.devotion of student and associate to
professor was more marked than
was the case in the Romance department. He was unselfish in
the extreme, and this unselfishness
had its effect in causing his department to be one of the most
harmonious in its work, that it
has been my privilege to know. I
only wish that in every department in every univiersity, there
could be manifested the same untiring devotion and self effacement."
Professor C. Carroll Marden
read a brief account of the life of
Dr. Elliott, and Professors Bright
and Gildersleeve `told of their relations with him as co-members of
the Hopkins faculty. Dr. Edward
C. Armstrong who is to head the
department of Romance languages
told of departmental relations with
Professor Elliott. Mr. George
Whitelock of the Baltimroe bar
spoke from the standpoint of a
friend who had known Dr. Elliott
for 35 years.

A successful season in Hopkins
athletics has just passed, and we
now look forward to further successes. Lacrosse opens its official
season with an organization meeting Thursday, December 8. Head
coach Meyer and assistant coaches
Lowndes and Frank will distribute
information and advice for the
first time in their official capacities.
A number of former Hopkins players and others interested will be
present.
Regular practice has been held
three times a week in the "cage,"
and Captain Hulburt is developing
a very promising squad. The
freshmen are showing up particularly well in their stick work even
at this early stage, and when the
regular lineup begins men of last
year's team may have their hands
"full holding their positions. The
loss of Edmund Clary, Pitts Ralleigh, and several medical men
will be severely felt. However,
there is left a good nucleus of last
year's team and this together with
the afore - mentioned promising
squad, while not by any means
in championship form as yet, furnishes a very good foundation on
which to build hopes for a championship lacrosse team in 1911.
Under Jake's tender care the
"cage" has recently assumed a "lacrosseable" shape. The tan bark has
been entirely removed, and the
ground is being constantly smoothed and watered. We shall miss
ex-coach Chesney's tow-head from
the middle of the "cage," but hope
to find him not infrequently at the
practices. Again, as always, "Bill"
Schmeisser will loom up in the
back-ground as a source of lacrosse
wisdom which can always be depended upon.
The schedule in -rapidly rounding into shape under Manager
li'akel's experienced management.
Games with Navy, Cornell, Harvard, Swarthmore, Lehigh, and
Stevens, are definitely settled;
games with Columbia, Carlisle,
and Mt. Washington are pending.
Every game will be played at Homewood except the Navy and Swarthmore games, and so this bids fair
to be one of the best schedules seen
at Homewood for some time.

BALTIMORE, MD., DEC. 5, 1910.

The selection of Dr. Edward F.
Buchner to fill, for the remainder
of this year, the place of Miss
Sarah C. Brooks at the Teachers'
Training School is a great tribute
to the strength and importance of
the youngest department at Flopkins—that of education.
Elsewhere in this issue, we print
one or two good stories clipped from
College World, a new and interesting monthly devoted to the interests
of undergraduates. These little
clashes in the class-room occur
everywhere and numbers of exceedingly funny ones have taken
place here at Hopkins.
Last year in ''Forensics 2," for
instance, Dr. French made the
statement that statistics proved that
married men, as a class, live longer
than single men. Quick as a flash
came the answer from "Teddy"
Will:
"That isn't true literally, Doctor,.
It just seems longer," and then the
class and instructor roared .
This is the kind of material that
TIIE NEWS-LEV-1'ER would like to
print,more of; and so fellows, when
something funny happens, write it
up and send it to us. We will be
glad to use it and you will give
others an opportunity to laugh at
what you think is a good joke.
Gifts to the amount of $13o,000
have been received by the Johns
Hopkins Committee on Endowment and extension during the
past week and certainly make the
outlook for raising of the fund
before the first of the year much
brighter. It came as a sort of
shock when the Committee announced that the whole of the
$75o,000 which has to be collected
in order to get the $250,000 offered
by the General Education Board

will have to be raised by local subscriptions, but the people of Baltimore are responding nobly, and
if contributions flow in at the present rate, no difficulty will be experienced in raising the necessary
funds.
The current issue of the Suwanee
Review contains an article from
the pen of Dr. William Hand
Browne, professor emeritus of English literature, an author whose
communications, Baltimoreans in
general, and Hopkins men in particular, are always glad to welcome.
Dr. Browne writes in an entertaining and scholarly fashion of the
various transformations undergone
by the story of Orpheus and Eurydice on its way from a classic
myth to a mediaeval fairy tale.
The statement of the New York
Evening Post to the effect that
there was here at Hopkins a socialist society in process of formation
does not seem to be as unfounded
as was at first thought. Just a day
before the illustrious Emma Goldman was scheduled to begin her
lectures in Baltimore, THE NEwsLETTER was given an exclusive tip
that some of th.?. students were
helping to advertise her speeches .
by distributing literature, inflammable in color and subject matter,
which represented Miss Goldman to
be the "most talented, but most misrepresented woman in the world,"
and urged everyone to come to the
four meetings.
Our "star reporter, whose name
we withhold for obvious reasons,
was sent out on the story, and
after a labored and careful investigation he discovered the following:
(I.) That eight red posters had
been placed in conspicuous positions in the lower corridor, where
the counterfeit presentments of
professors past and present gazed
benignly down on them.
(2.) That there were sixteen
cards of other colors in the corridor, and that all were prepared
with a view to augmenting socialistic sentiment among the readers.
(3.) That in the building, i. e.,
the classrooms, library, Y.M.C. A.,
etc., there were sixteen and onehalf cards. The missing half could
not be found, although a long and
painstaking search was conducted.
It is thought that some opponent
of the movement destroyed it.
This seems to be prima facie
evidence that some sort of sentiment favorable to the propaganda
of the Socialists exists at this University. We wish, therefore, to
reiterate our protest made in the
last issue of THE NEWS-LETTER,
that with the formation of the Arbitration Society and the rejuvenation of the Glee and Instrumental
Clubs, we have sufficient outside
activities to distract the mind from
study, and that if the door is once
opened to politic' organizations,
there will be no end nor limitation,
and the Republican, Democratic
and Prohibition sororities will immediately follow.

THE NEWS-LETTER, DECEMBER 5, 1910
SUMMER SCHOOL AT HOPKINS

FULTON IS AGAIN HONORED

Six Weeks' Session, from July 5th to
August 16th to be Given for
Teachers.

Star Hopkins Athlete is Elected Captain
of the Football Team for
Next Season:*

It has just been announced that
next summer a special six weeks'
course for teachers will be given
under the auspices of the Johns
Hopkins University. The work
will be designed primarily to meet
the personal and professional needs
of teachers. The school will be
under the direction of Dr. Edward
F. Buchner, professor of education,
and a large number of instructors,
selected because of their marked
ability as teachers and their interest in the special problems which
confront teachers, will co-operate.
The staff will comprise members
of the Hopkins Faculty and representatives from the faculties of
Other institutions. The complete
list will be announced at an early
date and a circular descriptive of
the courses offered will be issued.
It is in response to numerous
requests on the part of the administrators of the schools of Maryland,
and in the hope of increasing its service to the elementary and high
schools, that the University has
undertaken the summer session.
Ever since the beginning of instruction at Hopkins the University
has been noted for the lectures
Which were offered, entirely apart
from the formal courses which had
to be followed for the various degrees. The college courses for
teachers are now in the second year
Qf a very successful operation and
the extension of the work of the
University into this new field ought
to receive enthusiastic support.
Mr. George Lectures.

One of the most interesting and
instructive talks ever given in Levering Hall was given on Thursday
at five o'clock by Mr. W. R.
George, founder of the George
Junior Republic.
There are 175 boys and girls at
the Republic who govern themselves. They elect their own officers, have boy cops, jailers, bankers, and each boy and girl works
for his own living and pays his
board just as any other citizen of
the United States does. They also
have woman's sufferage and discuss all the political problems of
the American public life.

DR. MITCHELL DRAWS CROWD
McCoy Hall Packed to Hear Distinguished Neurologist and Author Lecture on "William Harvey."

That the Baltimore public is not
altogether indifferent to the lectures offered by the University, and
that the size of attendance depends
largely upon the extent of the
lecturer's popularity, was demonstrated last Monday night by the
unusually large and brilliant assembly which thronged McCoy
Hall to hear one of the most illustrious men whom the University
has recently had the honor to entertain. The venerable Dr. Silas
Weir Mitchell, now in his eightysecond year, poet, novelist, antiquarian, physician, and in all these
capacities distinguished, delivered,
at the invitation of the Johns Hopkins Hospital Historical Association, a lecture on "William Harvey," his spiritual ancestor, as he
fondly called him, and practically
the founder of the modern science
of medicine.
Dr. Mitchell is no narrow specialist, but a man of the broadest human interests ; and he treated his
subject, consequently, not as a
scientific abstraction, but as a living hero. He told of William
Harvey's boyhood in the little fishing town of Folkestone, on the
Kentish coast, of his sojourn as a
lesser pensioner at Cains College,
Cambridge; of his anatomical studies under Fabricius, at Aquapendente, at the great Italian University of Padua; of his graduation
from that venerable seat of learning with all the stately and impressive pomp so dear to Italian
tradition—the darkened theatre, the
robed senators of Venice; the opening of the closed books, the kiss
of peace, the goblet crown, the ring
of marriage to the University, the
presentation of the folded diploma.
Dr. Mitchell is a most charming
lecturer. He is not an orator; he
is a speaker of the old school; he
does not scruple to use a ringing
phrase or a flowery sentence when
he thinks such would be effective;
his delivery is hardly such as would
pass in public speaking. Yet it
is a pleasure to listen to him. His
venerable figure, his winning personality, his graceful humor, his
depth of thought, his breadth of
interest, his richness of allusion,
his great store of general knowledge, his youthful enthusiasm, combine to make him one of, the most
entertaining lecturers whom Hopkins has had the pleasure to hear
for a long time. May we enjoy
the pleasure soon again!

REMEMBER

This new volume which deals
with the principles of the science
of argumentation is proportioned
along slightly different lines from
previous educational works which
have been written on the same subject. The discussion of the fundamental principles is very brief, but
to the point, and by far the greater
part of the book is given up to
masterpieces of complete debates
on important questions which have
agitated the country. All of the
great figures in the Senate are represented in the collection, and
this, in addition to furnishing illustrations of the principles discussed
in the early part of the book has
the added advantage of giving to
the general reader these great debates in a collected form. The
manner of saying things in defense
of great principles is secondary to
what has been said, and it is just
as important to know what the
contentions of Lincoln and Webster were, as the manner in which
their arguments were presented.
This volume makes both possible.
In addition there is much new
material in the book on the subject
-of briefing and debating. This has
been carefully selected from the
field of actual contest and is based
on principles which have been
found to work in intercollegiate
debates, and is therefore helpful
because it is practical.

A big mass-meeting, to boost the
track team, will be held tomorrow
afternoon in the trophy room of
the gymnasium. Everyone should
be present, whether he intends to
join the squad or not, so as to
throw some life into the meeting
and make it a.success. A number of
Alumni will be present, and will
make speeches. Captain Fulton will
issue a formal call for candidates
at this meeting.
At the last meeting of the
Athletic Board, Rudolph Alfred
Kocher, a former star athlete of
Leland Stanford University, was
chosen coach of the team for this
year. William E. Hoffman, who
has coached the track squad several years, could not spare the time
necessary to accept the position
again. Kocher is at present attending the Hopkins Medical School.
He will speak at the mass-meeting
tomorrow.
Manager Harold B. Hering is
arranging one of the most ambitious
schedules a Hopkins track team
has ever had. He has a dual meet
with Columbia pending for May
6, and he has definitely scheduled
Pennsylvania, and the University
of Virginia.

Announcement was made Friday
morning that two men had passed
the Rhodes Scholarship examination held at Johns Hopkins University last October. The succesful
students are Bertram Benedict and
Harold Hering, both of whom are
Hor kins men.
Harold Hering is the president
of the senior class and manager
of this year's track team. He was
graduated from the Baltimore City
College in 1907, and has won
scholarships two years in succession at Hopkins. Bertram Benedict is also a graduate of the City
College, class of 1908. He is now
in the junior class at Johns Hopkins, where he took honors last
year.
There are two other candidates
eligible for the scholarship—M. R.
Reid, a graduate of Roanoke College, now a student at the Hopkins Medical School, and J. H.
Hendrickson, a graduate of Western Maryland College and the Harvard Law School. These men took
the examination last year, but
asked that they be considered in
this year's group of candidates.
From these four students one
man must be chosen. No further
examination will be held, but the
scholarship will be awarded by the
committee to the man who, in its
judgment, would best represent
his State and Nation at Oxford.
The general opinion among the
Hopkins undergraduates seems to
be that Harold Hering will receive
the honor. The popularity and athletic ability of the contestants is
generally taken into account. Her:,
ing is highly thought of both by
his classmates and the faculty, and
lie has made a creditable record as
an athlete.
The Rhodes scholarship carries
with it three years' residence at
Oxford, with full tuition and expenses, amounting in all to $1,500.
The recipients of .the scholarships
are granted special privileges.
They may become candidates for
In the
any degree they desire.
immense dining hall at Oxford
they sit at a table by themselves,
separated from the undergraduate
body, but close to the fellows, who
have a special table.
